Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 09:00AM - edited Sep 4, 2009 10:37AM by Wink Breakfast today included 1.5 cups Kashi GoLean, 1 cup 1% milk, 1 oz crasins, ~12 walnuts, and 1 banana.  Also had 1 cup coffee with Splenda & Half-n-Half. I'm usually pretty good through lunch - it's the afternoon & late night munchies that get to me!  I need to drink more water too.  We had a PT who specializes in lymphedema speak at our last ACS support group meeting.  She said that you need to drink 1/2 oz of water for every pound you weigh - man - I'll be spending half the day in the water closet! OK, could have done better at lunch.  Chicken Taco salad (no sour cream) with a few chips.  Low fat peanut butter frozen yogurt with a squirt of Hershey's chocolate (it was soooo yummy) and water.
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2009 05:30PM - edited Sep 7, 2009 05:30PM by Wink Everyone is welcome - Howdy Lia1964 & Sunflowers! I washed windows and screens today - that had to count for something!  I'm working a 12.5 hr night shift tonight and tomorrow night; it's really difficult to not "graze" all night.  I tried to bring healthy snacks.  I've been drinking lots of water today. Juli - can you swim?  Christine - kudos for the gym and for passing on the desserts - that's my weakness. I try to remember that cancer loves sugar - so I should not! Last year I went on a refined sugar fast - after ~2 weeks I stopped craving sugar; I'm going to do the same now - bye,bye Klondike bars ;-(
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 12:15AM Wink wrote: Juli - yes, there are water aerobics - no head dunking required!
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 07:21PM Wink wrote: I didn't lose this week either - I'm thinking of buying weight-watchers meals again; that seemed to work for me last time.  Jane, that may be something you could do after your husband has his lap-band.  Most of the WW meals are pretty tasty. And if you  have a Super Wal-Mart around - they're only about $2 a meal.  I'm allowed to have 27 points a day - when I follow it - it works.  My DH is 6'4" and weighs ~ 195; he's a southern boy and like his "supper"; I just can't eat the same things he does!
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 11:23AM Wink wrote: Welcome Susie!  Glad that you joined this bunch of losers (at least I hope I'll be a loser)...lol Hey Juli - I got deported when I had my tissue expanders placed in early July - what a nice feeling that was.  I hope that you get to enjoy deportation too. Last night I did pretty good - 2 small slices of roasted pork loin (very lean), coleslaw, and baked sweet tater.  Had a "no sugar added" Klondike bar (didn't have to do anything for it either).  Went to bed and dog-gone-it had to get up and have some pudding - 3 cups at 60 cal each = 180 - could be worse - could be better
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 03:20PM Wink wrote: Chris - it's probably just water weight.  Is the Bolly Jolly class a dance class - like the dances in the Bollywood movies?  I bet that would be fun! I've got to get serious - no more excuses!  On my onc's scale last Thurs, I weighed 4 lbs more than I do on my scales at home-YIKES!!!!  I've been trying to watch Dr Oz everyday as inspiration - it does help to a certain extent (at least until my sweettooth screams at me). I need to start exercising while watching Dr Oz..lol! Jane - just remember, you can behave as soon as you get home from the fair. Hope you had a good time!
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 08:53AM Wink wrote: We went on a camping trip last weekend and blew all of the "good" eating out of the water!  I've been trying to be good this week.  When I got on my Wii balance board, it weighed me at 1.5 lbs gain from last time (which had a 1.8 loss); so I'm 0.3 lbs down...lol Susie - I'm so sorry to hear of the passing of your brother; it is a comfort to know that his pain has ended. Jane - I'm not counting calories either.  I'm trying to stay away from sugar and refined carbs.  The author of The Zone diet said that a correct portion size is the size of you palm; must keep this in mind!  My sweet-tooth is my biggest downfall. Chris - I think that we are programmed as children that rewards = food.  I remember going out for desert after a recital or concert; receiving special treats when down or hurt; comfort = food.  And of course the "clean plate" club doesn't help either (can't tell you how many times I heard about the starving children in China).  These are lifelong habits that were instilled in me - I have to think of other ways to reward myself...new shoes, new outfit, massage, facial, something other than food. Lisa - I'm right there with ya GF; triple negative, apple shaped, same height, I weigh about15 pounds more that you, would also love to lose 30 lbs by May...and then 20 more after that! What part of GA is Paulding County?  I live 10 miles north of Dillard, GA.
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Wink wrote: Hey Girlfriends, I added some junk to my trunk (boot & bonnet) during and after treatment.  Diet and exercise are supposed to contribute to happy, healthy bods & brains (I certainly need help with both - ChemoBelly & ChemoBrain ). SingaporeChris suggested that we start a weight loss topic for all of us who need support (I'm not talking about foundation garments Ladies).  You don't have to list your weight if you don't want to - maybe just the amount that you want to lose to reach your goal; no real rules - just support and encouragement. Let's choose a day to weigh in (I like Friday - just in case you slip up on the weekend); post your losses; write down your daily intake - calories or points, whatever you're into; provide weight loss tips; recipes; exercises, etc. Let's get healthy Ladies! Donna (aka Wink)  Short term goal; lose 5 lbs by Oct 1st                                 Long term goal ; lose 45 lbs by  June 2010 Donna "There Are No Accidents" Dx 7/25/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 07:06PM Wink wrote: Chris, yes I did receive the collage....thank you so much. We had a bunch of people here at work that joined WW; we started the first week in Nov.  At last weigh-in, I was down 10.5 pounds!  Had Christmas at my brother's and probably blew all of my points for the week, but I'm back on track today.  We don't have another weigh-in until Jan 7, so hopefully I'll be down a couple of pounds by then.  I'm down a dress size and it feels so good - can't wait to drop down another!
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 03:39PM Wink wrote: Chris - is there a vision board for losing weight?
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 04:59PM Wink wrote: Wonderful Chris!  I will weight in tomorrow - had a CAT scan and working a 12.5 hour night shift - forgot about it being weigh-in day.  My husband and I (and our 3 furry babies) walked all over the mountain Wed & Thurs; will walk tomorrow when I wake up. Doesn't that totally bum you out; you're walking fast, sweating, and feeling pretty good about it and you've only walked off an oatmeal raisin cookie!  Another thing I hate is that you can't kill a fat cell (unless of course you have it sucked out), but sneeze the wrong way and you kill a brain cell! OK - I'll work on "positive" now.  Probably lost a lot of weight (albeit water weight) from the after effects of two bottles of contrast - not a fun way to lose! Chris - please PM me the vision board instructions. Thinking Slim!

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 12:11PM Wink wrote: Ugh!  Didn't lose any weight last week - which doesn't surprise me. I worked 3-12.5 hr night shifts and I felt like I was constantly eating (which I was) to stay awake.  I'm back to my regular dayshift and hopefully will do better this week.  I did find a really good low calorie (60 each cup) pudding - I think it's made by Jello - it's like a creme caramel - yummy!  Now if I can restrict myself to only 1 . Today I had my organic Fiber cereal w/banana & almonds & 1% organic milk for breakfast; Kashi red curry chicken frozen meal with green beans & vanilla low cal pudding. Here's hoping that I can make it through the afternoon & evening without ravishing the pantry! Chris - you need to post your cheesecake recipe - do you use artificial sweetner too? Come on Jane - join us!  Juli - hope all goes well with your PET scan.  I had a CAT scan last Friday and would have sworn that I'd lost some weight because of the lovely cocktail & side-effects that it induces.
Posts.Title: Chemo Sept 08; Let's Shed Weight! Wink Wink

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 08:49PM Wink wrote: I do so well during the day - there's something about nighttime that triggers the grazing mechanism in me.  Plus - now that it's officially Fall - the average person gains 10 lbs in the fall; just what I need! I got a message in my work e-mail that we are trying to get a WW's group going here at work.  The hospital will give us incentive $$ for reaching 10% goal and staying in for 15 weeks.  We have to have at least 20 people to do so. I hope we get enough folks, this would be a good thing for me.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 01:49AM Wink wrote: It is interesting to see the different instructions in care.  I was told that I could not take a shower until my drains were out and scabbed over.  I washed my hair in the sink and then washed the southern exposure in the tub.  My drains came out one week after my bilat mast - I was still producing about 30 mLs of fluid. My surgeon checked  me the next day and told me that there was a little fluid under the skin, but nothing that he was worried about.  It's been a little over three weeks now; the SNB sites bother me more than anything - can only sleep on my back.

Posts.Title: Need to decide one breast or two? catemarie catemarie

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 07:40AM Wink wrote: LML, I hope that all went well for you today.  I had my surgery on the 18th and was released from the hospital this morning.  I feel surprisingly well and have minimal pain.  I did find out that getting dressed is a little dicey.  I made the mistake of putting on my jeans this morning and highly recommend loose pull-on pants.  Catemarie, have you had your surgery yet? I really had to stand my ground with my surgeon to get a bilateral; I also had to dig in my heels to get a high-dose IV vitamin C (had this with my abdominal hysterectomy and went back to work in less than 2 weeks). Thank you all for the well wishes - it's wonderful to have a support system.
Posts.Title: Need to decide one breast or two? catemarie catemarie

Posts.Content: Wink wrote: I was diagnosed July 25,2008 with IDC, grade 3, ER-/PR-, waiting for HER2 results.  All of this after finding my birth family after 50 years. Finally I have a family medical history...no breast cancer on either side!  I was on such a high from finding my mother, father, and two brothers (my parents got married a year after I was born) and finding out that they lived only 70 miles from where I live!  They have been such a blessing and are great support for me (my adoptive mother is deceased and my adoptive father is almost 90 and lives in Florida).  I truly think that the Lord works in mysterious ways (and apparently has a snarky sense of humor). I had my CAT scan on Friday and will be meeting with my surgeon on Tuesday afternoon.  I have decided that I want to have a bi-lateral mastectomy and my husband is in agreement.  Why go through the stress and anxiety of having bc in the other breast. I think that it will be worth alleviating that stress alone!  I've seen the after-photos and know that it is not a pretty sight, but can always opt for re-constructive surgery down the road. I work in a hospital laboratory as a Clinical Laboratory Scientist and I see the worse-case scenarios; it does haunt me.  It makes it hard not to think the worst.  I have had incredible support from my co-workers (including the pathologist who worked up my biopsy - he's the lab director) and I feel that all are rallying to help.  My fears are associated with the fact that I have to work full-time to maintain my insurance and I know that I will be putting myself at risk during chemo.  Those of you who have had to continue working full time during chemo, can you offer me any advice? Donna "There Are No Accidents" Dx 7/25/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 06:56AM Wink wrote: Hi Jose - what a thoughtful boyfriend you are!  I've not heard or read anything about not being around fresh cut flowers.  I think that flowers would be wonderful.  I would not send any that are overly fragrant; it seems that your sense of smell becomes very acute and scents that you normally like become overpowering.  Best wishes for you both! Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 06:40PM Wink wrote: I started the bisphosphonate trial Nov 18, 2008; I'm in the ibandronate (Boniva) arm of the trial.  I have had some large muscle pain, but seem to be doing well otherwise.  Brena - I have the same dx as you; my onc highly recommended the trial because I am a triple negative and once we're done with chemo, we're done.  He felt that this was a proactive step that I could take. I'm 50 and was premenapausal before chemo. Donna
Posts.Title: bisphosphonates joanne_elizabeth brena

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 10:29AM Wink wrote: Bisphosphonate trial update.  I saw my onc last Thurs and he told me that he'd recently been to a conference where they updated some of their findings regarding the trial.  They are finding that not only do the drugs appear to prevent mets of the bone, but it seems to prevent (or reduce) mets to soft tissue too; lets hope that this is true! Donna

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 05:32PM Wink wrote: Has anyone had any jaw issues?  My 1st molar upper left needed to be re-filled (old filling was coming out) before I started chemo in Sept.  Now it is very cold sensitive and I'm have some pain (but doesn't hurt all of the time).  My coordinator told me that most of the cases of osteonecrosis were in folks that had poor dental hygiene. Hope y'all are well!
